citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Approximately 3 weeks ago, after finding a Canada goose dead floating in the pool of its enclosure, the facility failed to
notify the Attending Veterinarian (AV). Failure to ensure the AV has the appropriate authority for adequate veterinary care
may put the other animals at risk of a contagious disease or negatively impact their health and well-being. Exhibiting
facilities must assure that the attending veterinarian has appropriate authority to ensure the provision of adequate
veterinary care and to oversee the adequacy of other aspects of animal care and use.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
In the Infirmary, a medication cabinet labelled for exhibit animals contained medications that were not adequately labeled
and/or were out of date. There was an unlabeled squeeze bottle containing a blue liquid, a container labeled Quickstop
with no instructions or manufacturing information on it, and a bag of syringes labeled dexamethasone that expired
01/01/2019. Medical supplies that are not properly labeled and/or not properly stored, could deteriorate, become
contaminated, or be misused, possibly resulting in harm to the health and well-being of the animals. Medicines used to
prevent or treat disease must be properly stored, labeled, and not expired in order for them to appropriately and
effectively prevent, control, and/or treat diseases.

Multiple enclosures housing several different species of birds had walls with exposed damaged plywood and/or
particleboard that was not able to be effectively cleaned and sanitized. Primary enclosures must be constructed and
maintained so that all surfaces in contact with the birds may be readily cleaned and/or sanitized in accordance with 3.158
or be replaced when worn or soiled.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Ten primary enclosures, housing a total of 69 birds, were dirty with a buildup of wet excrement, food waste, and spider
webs covering the walls and floors. Insufficient cleaning can lead to disease hazards, insects, pest and odors. Excreta
and food waste must be removed from within, under, and around the primary enclosure often enough to prevent
excessive accumulation.

Approximately 3 weeks ago, a female Canada goose housed with 3 other Canada Geese and 2 Indian Runner Ducks was
found dead floating in the enclosure’s pool. When questioned, facility employees reported that seasonal aggression has
been observed and believed the dead goose had been drowned by its cage mates. Animals housed in the same primary
enclosure must be compatible and cannot interfere with the health of other animals or cause them discomfort.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by Jul16,2024 (date the current license expires) or the
applicant will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your
next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(a)(2)  Critical
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Approximately 3 weeks ago, after finding a Canada goose dead floating in the pool of its enclosure, the facility failed to 
notify the Attending Veterinarian (AV). Failure to ensure the AV has the appropriate authority for adequate veterinary care 
may put the other animals at risk of a contagious disease or negatively impact their health and well-being. Exhibiting 
facilities must assure that the attending veterinarian has appropriate authority to ensure the provision of adequate 
veterinary care and to oversee the adequacy of other aspects of animal care and use. 
2.40(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
In the Infirmary, a medication cabinet labelled for exhibit animals contained medications that were not adequately labeled 
and/or were out of date. There was an unlabeled squeeze bottle containing a blue liquid, a container labeled Quickstop 
with no instructions or manufacturing information on it, and a bag of syringes labeled dexamethasone that expired 
01/01/2019. Medical supplies that are not properly labeled and/or not properly stored, could deteriorate, become 
contaminated, or be misused, possibly resulting in harm to the health and well-being of the animals. Medicines used to 
prevent or treat disease must be properly stored, labeled, and not expired in order for them to appropriately and 
effectively prevent, control, and/or treat diseases. 
3.153(a)(1)(ix)  Repeat
   
Primary enclosures. 
Multiple enclosures housing several different species of birds had walls with exposed damaged plywood and/or 
particleboard that was not able to be effectively cleaned and sanitized. Primary enclosures must be constructed and 
maintained so that all surfaces in contact with the birds may be readily cleaned and/or sanitized in accordance with 3.158 
or be replaced when worn or soiled. 
3.158(a)(1)  Repeat
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
Ten primary enclosures, housing a total of 69 birds, were dirty with a buildup of wet excrement, food waste, and spider 
webs covering the walls and floors. Insufficient cleaning can lead to disease hazards, insects, pest and odors. Excreta

and food waste must be removed from within, under, and around the primary enclosure often enough to prevent 
excessive accumulation. 
3.160(b)  Critical
   
Compatibility and separation 
Approximately 3 weeks ago, a female Canada goose housed with 3 other Canada Geese and 2 Indian Runner Ducks was 
found dead floating in the enclosure’s pool. When questioned, facility employees reported that seasonal aggression has 
been observed and believed the dead goose had been drowned by its cage mates. Animals housed in the same primary 
enclosure must be compatible and cannot interfere with the health of other animals or cause them discomfort. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by Jul16,2024 (date the current license expires) or the 
applicant will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your 
next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
